Graphical abstract Vapor-phase-etching hard-template (VEHT) method can directly fabricate a series of tubular materials. TiO2− x tubes were used as model to illustrate their structure evolution mechanism of Rayleigh instability by in-situ TEM and good Na+ storage performances. Inorganic tubular materials have an exceptionally wide range of applications, yet developing a simple and universal method to controllably synthesize them remains challenging. In this work, we report a vapor-phase-etching hard-template method that can directly fabricate tubes on various thermally stable oxide and sulfide materials. This synthesis method features the introduction of a vapor-phase-etching process to greatly simplify the steps involved in preparing tubular materials and avoids complicated post-processing procedures. Furthermore, the in-situ heating transmission electron microscopy (TEM) technique is used to observe the dynamic formation process of TiO2− x tubes, indicating that the removal process of the Sb2S3 templates first experienced the Rayleigh instability, then vapor-phase-etching process. When used as an anode for sodium ion batteries, the TiO2− x tube exhibits excellent rate performance of 134.6 mA h g−1 at the high current density of 10 A g− 1 and long-term cycling over 7000 cycles. Moreover, the full cell demonstrates excellent cycling performance with capacity retention of 98% after 1000 cycles, indicating that it is a promising anode material for batteries. This method can be expanded to the design and synthesis of other thermally-stable tubular materials such as ZnS, MoS2, and SiO2. Keywords Tubular materials In-situ heating TEM Sodium ion batteries TiO2 Hard template methods 1 Introduction Tubular structures, with inner voids and outer shells, have attracted abundant research attention due to their advantages of large surface area, low density, and intrinsic channels for charge and mass transport [1–4]. These unique properties enable them to have a wide range of applications in various fields, including catalysis [5,6], guest encapsulation [7,8], electromagnetic wave absorption [9,10], nanofabrication [11,12], biomedical applications [13,14], etc. In particular, tubular materials bring many benefits to electrochemical energy storage technologies [15–18], owing to their structure-induced properties: (i) their large specific surface area can provide ion/charge storage active sites and increase the electrode–electrolyte contact; (ii) their open channels can facilitate transmission and migration of ions and electrons; and (iii) their internal void space can relax the volume expansion caused by ion insertion [19,20]. Controllable preparation of tubular materials is not a simple task, however. The most used strategies are template-assisted (hard or soft templates and self-templated), as well as self-assembly, electrospinning, electrodeposition, biomass derivation, etc. [21–25]. Among them, electrospinning, electrodeposition and biomass derivation methods are too restrictive and uncontrollable to be widely used. For template-assisted methods, a series of oxides (SiO2 [26], ZnO [27], MoO3 [10], etc.), metal nanowires (Cu [19], Te [28], etc.), and organic materials (polystyrene [29], etc.) are widely selected templates used to obtain tubular structures. Although they would encounter the challenges of choosing appropriate template systems, efficient removal of templates, and forming target materials with the desired composition. Meanwhile, the post-treatment process in the hard template method is harsh and complex, which requires strong acids, bases, or organic solvents, easily destroying the tubular structure or the composition of the final products. For example, to synthesize carbon material with the novel tube-in-tube structure, 2 M NaOH solution was needed to remove the SiO2 templates. [30] Multi-step processing is another obstacle, such as obtaining a unique carbon nanotube (CNT)-wired MoS2 hierarchical tubular structures using polyacrylonitrile (PAN) as a template, which went through many steps involving an oil bath, a hydrothermal method, the strong acid HCl solution, and a high-temperature annealing treatment [31]. These complex steps not only cause irreversible resource consumption, but also reduce the yield of the target product. Although the formation of tubular structure is simple, to develop a universal, controllable, and efficient approach to preparing it remains a big challenge. Furthermore, in-situ observations of the dynamic structural evolution can make it possible to gain an in-depth understanding of the formation mechanism. Compared with the commonly used in-situ spectroscopy techniques (in-situ X-ray diffraction (in-situ XRD), in-situ Raman spectroscopy, etc.), which can only provide the information of phase transitions, in-situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) can provide intuitive observations. Thanks to the rapid development of in-situ TEM techniques, there has been great progress on observing the formation process of nanomaterials, as well as their electrochemical behavior, catalytic behavior, and so on [32]. For example, the morphology and structural evolution of iron oxide nanocapsules due to the shell-induced Ostwald ripening has been analyzed, illustrating the importance of in-situ microscopy for collecting the real-time information during the reaction process [33]. Moreover, the in-situ heating TEM can solve the challenge of observing what happens during the reaction process at a high temperature. To the best of our knowledge, the in-situ observation of tubular materials at a high temperature has not been reported. In this work, a novel vapor-phase-etching hard-template (VEHT) method was developed to synthesize a series of pure phase tubular metal oxides or sulfides without extra post-treatment. By taking advantage of an in-situ heating TEM, real-time information on the removal of inner templates was recorded. Here, TiO2, with the advantages of low-price, non-toxicity, and high chemical stability was used as an example to investigate the morphological evolution of tubular structures and their energy storage potential [34,35]. Specifically, in-situ heating TEM was conducted to observe the removal process of the inner templates in real time, illustrating the Rayleigh instability of the templates under high temperature. In addition, the obtained TiO2− x tubes were used as anode for sodium ion batteries (SIBs), and satisfactory long-term cycling and rate performances were obtained. Our work fills the gap in in-situ observation of the preparation of nanomaterials under variable temperature conditions based on hard-template methods. It is likely to be of great significance for guiding the design and synthesis of other thermally-stable tubular materials. 2 Results and discussion TiO2− x tubes were successfully synthesized from core-shell Sb2S3@TiO2 rods by a vapor-etching-process in Ar/H2 atmosphere, as illustrated in Fig. 1 (a). Initially, the rod-shaped precursor Sb2S3 was obtained by solvothermal reaction [36], as shown in the TEM and scanning electron microscope (SEM) images (Fig. S1a and b). The diffraction peaks of the XRD pattern correspond well to orthorhombic Sb2S3 (Fig. S1c). Then, the Sb2S3 rods, serving as a hard template, were coated with a TiO2 layer, which is confirmed by the TEM image (Fig. S2 a). The thickness of the coating layer is ∼54 nm. To further confirm the successful coating, Fourier transformed infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was conducted on the Sb2S3@TiO2 composite. The stretching vibration mode of Ti-O-Ti at around 600 cm−1 was detected (Fig. S2b) [37]. As shown in Fig. S2(c), there are no clear XRD peaks related to TiO2 in the Sb2S3@TiO2 composite, suggesting the amorphous nature of the coated TiO2 layer. The calcination temperature of Sb2S3@TiO2 composite was 600 °C which can enable the reduced product of Sb2S3, metallic Sb, be completely removed (Fig. S3). Hence, the final product, anatase TiO2− x tubes (JCPDS Card, No. 21–1272), was obtained (Fig. 1b). Because of the reducing atmosphere (Ar/H2) and the high calcination temperature, some oxygen vacancies (OVs) were expected to be introduced into the TiO2 to generate the TiO2− x , which can be confirmed by Raman spectra, and the electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) and XPS spectra [38,39]. Here, commercial anatase TiO2 nanoparticles were used as a comparison (Fig. S4). As shown in the Raman spectrum (Fig. 1c), the peak at ∼150 cm−1 belonging to the Eg mode of TiO2 is clearly identified. The inset of Fig. 1(c) shows that this characteristic peak of TiO2− x tube has a slight blue shift compared with the commercial TiO2, confirming the presence of oxygen vacancy in the product [39]. There were no identifiable peaks of carbon in the Raman spectrum (Fig. S5), so the broad peak at ∼25° in Fig. 1(b) is due to the small size effect and bulk defects of TiO2− x tubes. Further evidence comes from the EPR data, in which the signal at the g-factor, g = 2.003 is associated with OVs (Fig. 1d) [38]. Moreover, in the XPS spectra, the shift of the high-resolution spectra of Ti 2p (Fig. 1e) demonstrates the existence of reduced Ti species (Ti3+) in the TiO2− x tubes [40]. The peak located at 531.7 eV in the high-resolution O 1s spectrum (Fig. 1f) further reveals the existence of OVs. The DC resistance measurement results acquired with four-point probe method showed that the electronic conductivity of TiO2− x tubes is 1.42 × 10−5 S cm−1, which is much higher than commercial TiO2 nanoparticles (2.43 × 10−9 S cm−1). Therefore, such a large amount of OVs is believed to increase the electronic conductivity and reduce the charge-transfer resistance between the electrolyte and electrode, which will benefit the sodium storage performance of TiO2− x tubes. The absence of Sb and S signals in the XPS spectra of TiO2− x tubes (Fig. S6) shows the complete disappearance of the inner templates and the acquisition of pure phase products. The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm of TiO2− x tube shown in Fig. 1(g) reflects the specific surface area of 114.7 m2 g−1, which can provide a large effective interface between the electrode and electrolyte. Moreover, the combination of the OVs and tubular structure will increase the concentration of charge carriers in the tubes and reduce the band gap of the material, thereby guiding the rapid transmission of sodium ions afterwards [41,42]. The dual control strategy based on structure and morphology was realized in the preparation of TiO2− x tubes. Initially, TEM was employed to investigate the morphology of a typical region of Sb2S3@TiO2 composite (Fig. 2a and Fig. S2a). The outer TiO2 layer can be easily distinguished by its different contrasts. Moreover, the lattice fringes with spacing of 0.38 nm (determined by FFT of the image) could be assigned to the (202) planes of Sb2S3 (Fig. 2b). The absence of lattice fringes on the outer coating layer further confirms the amorphous properties of the TiO2 which is in good agreement with its XRD pattern (Fig. S2b). Furthermore, the elemental mapping images in Fig. 2(c) demonstrates the uniform distribution of the amorphous TiO2 coating on the surfaces of Sb2S3 nanorods. After the vapor etching process under Ar/H2 atmosphere, the template was removed. TiO2− x completely inherited its one-dimensional (1D) shape from Sb2S3@TiO2 rods with a typical hollow structure (Fig. 2d and Fig. S7). By magnifying part of the TiO2− x nanotubes, the wall of the nanotube is composed of randomly oriented but crystallized TiO2− x nanoparticles (Fig. S7a). The high-resolution TEM image in Fig. 2(e) clearly displays lattice fringes with the spacing of 0.35 nm, corresponding to the (101) planes of anatase TiO2. Moreover, energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping analysis of the TiO2− x tube in Fig. 2(f) does not show the signals of Sb and S (Fig. S8), indicating that the template had been totally removed, which is consistent with the XPS spectra (Fig. S6). Using hard templates to prepare tubular or porous materials was widely adopted in previous studies because of its simplicity and controllability, although almost no attention has been paid to understanding their dynamic structural transformation of the synthesis process [43,44]. Here, in this case, owing to the fast development of the in-situ TEM technique, the formation process of TiO2− x nanotubes by a hard template method can be directly visualized, which will help us to gain an in-depth understanding of the synthetic methodology of the VEHT method. Fig. 2(g) shows in-situ TEM images of the formation process of TiO2− x nanotubes at different stages, and the video of the whole synthesis process is presented in Video S1. To ensure the representativeness of the sample, the observed Sb2S3@TiO2 microrod sample was selected with the inner template length of 372 nm and the cladding layer thickness of 56 nm (Fig. 2g-1). After heating to 600 °C, the Sb2S3 template was broken from the middle (Fig. 2g–2), and then it gradually disappeared from the rupture to the ends of the tube, due to the Rayleigh instability assisted by the volume shrinkage created by the reduction process of Sb2S3 [45,46]. As indicated by the XRD pattern of the obtained products after heating (Fig. S3 a), the precursor Sb2S3@TiO2 was first reduced to Sb metal in its molten state because of the high temperature of 600 °C. Subsequently, molten Sb would volatilize directly under the rapid Ar/H2 airflow or vacuum. Moreover, the outer layer of TiO2 is not very dense, which provides tiny channels for the removal of the inner template. After high temperature treatment, the obtained TiO2-x tube is composed of nanocrystals (Fig. 2g–5). The outer wall of the TiO2-x tube is made up of aggregates of particles due to the high temperature annealing, which might be caused by the seed-mediated growth of TiO2 and the heterogeneous shrinkage of Sb and TiO2 after the gasification of S [47,48]. This VEHT method can enable the formation of tubular structures without post-treatment. The final product, TiO2− x nanotube, has massive defects and abundant tiny channels between the TiO2 crystals, which could provide more active Na-ion storage sites, while the tubular shape could facilitate the diffusion of sodium ions and electrons. The sodium storage performance of TiO2− x tubes was investigated. Fig. 3(a) presents their CV curves at the scan rate of 0.2 mV s−1. Here, the reduction peaks at approximately 0.2–0.02 V in the first cycle can be assigned to the irreversible phase transition, and they vanish in the subsequent cycles [49]. The broad cathodic peak at 0.58 V shown in the third cycle can be assigned to the reduction of Ti4+ to Ti3+ along with the sodium ion intercalation, and the anodic peak at 0.81 V corresponds to the extraction process of Na+ [50,51]. All the voltage platforms that appear in the discharge/charge profiles in Fig. 3(b) at 0.1 A g−1 agree well with the redox peaks in the CV curves. The main voltage plateaus present at 0.5–1.2 V correspond to the reversible insertion/extraction of sodium ions in anatase TiO2 [41]. TiO2− x tubes deliver discharge and charge capacities of 319 and 246 mA h g−1 during the first cycle, respectively, with a coulombic efficiency of 77.1%, which is higher than that for a large proportion of reports on TiO2 as anode for SIBs [38–40]. In addition, Fig. 3(c) shows that the TiO2− x tube electrode displays superior long-term cycling performance with 95.1% capacity retention after 4000 cycles, which is higher than for commercial TiO2 nanoparticles (71.8%). Moreover, the excellent electrochemical stability of TiO2− x tube is also reflected in the rate performance (Fig. 3d). The discharge capacities were 250.4, 221.1, 201.4, 188.3, 172.8, 153.8, and 134.6 mA h g−1 at the current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 5 and 10Ag−1, respectively. To explore the reasons for superior rate performance, the charge/discharge profiles of TiO2− x tubes at various rate densities are shown in Fig. 3(e). The shape of these voltage profiles indicate that the TiO2− x tubes have fast kinetics as well as high specific capacity. When the TiO2− x tube electrodes encounter a large current density, the polarization does not increase as much as for the commercial nanoparticles (Fig. S9), indicating that the TiO2− x tubes have faster kinetics as well as higher specific capacity. In addition, the TiO2− x tube anode was tested by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) after 10 cycles to further confirm the superior kinetic properties. As shown in Fig. 3(f) and Table S1, the charge-transfer resistance (R ct) of TiO2− x tubes is ∼50% lower than that of commercial TiO2 nanoparticles. The synergistic effect from the introduction of oxygen vacancy, the unique structure of the active material and the mixed conducting network of TiO2− x tubes are why they exhibit better cycling stability and kinetic behavior than for irregular TiO2 nanoparticles in SIBs. At the high current density of 5Ag−1, there is still a reversible capacity of 152 mA h g−1 remaining after 7000 cycles, as shown in Fig. 3(g). Even at the high current density of 10Ag−1, a specific capacity of 114 mA h g−1 is retained after 9000 cycles (Fig. S10). This rate performance of TiO2− x tubes is better than for many other TiO2-based materials, as shown in Fig. 3(h) [40,50,52–55]. To further understand the superior sodium-ion storage performance of TiO2− x tubes, Galvano-static intermittent titration technique (GITT) measurements were conducted during the Na+ storage process to measure the transfer kinetics of Na ions, as shown in Fig. 4 (a). Correspondingly, the diffusion coefficient of Na+ for TiO2− x tubes was calculated to be higher than for TiO2 nanoparticles (Fig. 4b), indicating that the tubular materials can provide a way for the rapid transmission of electrolyte ions to occur and shorten the ion diffusion length in electrodes. The existence of defects in bulk TiO2− x tubes can also provide much better electronic conductivity [23]. Furthermore, the CV curves of TiO2− x tubes under increasing scan rates ranging from 0.2 to 2.0 mV s−1 were collected to analyze their electrochemical reaction kinetics (Fig. 4c). Basically, all the curves showed similar contours, and the b parameter values of cathodic/anodic peaks of TiO2 were calculated as shown in Fig. 4(d). The b value is in terms of the slope of the logarithm of the peak current vs the logarithm of scan rate as shown in Eq. (1) [56]. (1) i = a v b where the b values of 0.97/0.86 indicate a mixed contribution of diffusion-controlled (b = 0.5) and capacitive-controlled (b = 1) processes. Notably, the capacitive process contribution of TiO2− x tubes is 94.5% of the overall capacity at 1.2 mV s−1 (Fig. 4e), and it is steady up to 96.7% at 2.0 mV s−1 (Fig. 4f). In short, due to the unique tubular nanostructures and the oxygen defects, a higher pseudo-capacitance ratio, faster ion transmission, and lower charge transfer resistance of TiO2− x tube were all achieved, making them suitable for the anode of sodium ion batteries. In view of the outstanding sodium-ion storage performances of TiO2− x tubes in half cells, TiO2− x tubes were further investigated in full cells with home-made Na3V2(PO4)3@C (NVP@C) as the cathode (Fig. 4g). The morphology and structural characterization of NVP@C are shown in Fig. S11 [57], and the charge/discharge profiles and long-term cycling performance of the NVP@C half-cell are shown in Fig. S12. The mass loading of the cathode was calculated as 2.5 times that of the anode to ensure the capacity ratio of negative to positive electrodes (N/P) electrodes was about 1:1.2. The voltage window of the TiO2− x tube//NVP@C full cell was between 1.5–3.1 V, in which the average output voltage was about 2.3 V (Fig. S13a). The energy density of the full cells is estimated to be 103 W h kg−1 according to the third cycle. Fig. 4(h) shows that the TiO2− x tube//NVP@C full cell presented average capacities of 121, 112, 106, 98, 92, 86, and 76 mA h g−1 at various current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, and 3.0Ag−1, respectively. Good rate reversibility is illustrated by the full cell’s ability to maintain the discharge capacity of 116 mA h g−1 when the current density went back to 0.1 A g−1. As the current density increased, the shapes of the charge/discharge profiles were well retained (Fig. S13b). Based on the superior performances of the half cells, the cycling stability was also tested at the current density of 0.5Ag−1 (Fig. 4i). The TiO2− x tube//NVP@C sodium ion full cell maintained stable operation for over 1000 cycles with a discharge capacity of 134 mA h g−1. Meanwhile, the battery exhibited a coulombic efficiency of more than 99.5% afterwards and a slight capacity increase during cycling, indicating a perfect kinetics match between the cathode and the anode. These good properties of the full cell suggest that TiO2− x tube has the potential for practical application in SIBs. Because of the superior cycling and rate performances of TiO2− x tubes in SIBs, the advantages of tubular materials in energy storage should be fully recognized. To deeply understand the sodiation/de-sodiation mechanism of TiO2− x tube, in-situ Raman spectra and synchrotron XRD were performed for the initial cycle (Fig. 5 a). In the Raman spectra, the peak of Eg mode gradually disappeared in the first sodiation process, indicating the transformation of TiO2− x tube from anatase phase to amorphous phase (Fig. 5b) [50]. After firstly being charged to 2.5 V, the Eg mode did not appear. The same phenomenon is observed in the in-situ synchrotron XRD in which the (101) peak can be detected initially (Fig. 5c), and then a slight shift to the left side occurred in the sequence of scan 1,10, and 15 (Fig. S14), showing the lattice expansion of (101) due to the sodium insertion. Raman and XRD analysis indicated that sodium ions can intercalate into TiO2− x tubes, inducing the transformation from anatase to amorphous phase which is irreversible (Fig. S15). Notably, the phase amorphization during the initial cycle didn’t broke the tubular structure of TiO2− x , neither after the long-term repeated cycles (Fig. S16). This VEHT strategy is simple for the preparation of high-quality tubular materials. For example, SiO2 tubes (Fig. 6 a–c) were successfully obtained from the precursor Sb2S3@SiO2 composites (Fig. S17). In addition to the oxides, sulfides can also be synthesized, benefiting from the sulfur source in the Sb2S3. As a demonstration, a series of sulfides such as ZnS (Fig. 6d–f) and MoS2 (Fig. 6g–i) have been successfully prepared by this method (Figs. S18 and S19). Meanwhile, their corresponding XRD patterns, and their TEM and SEM images are shown in Fig. 6. They all keep their tubular structure after a simple vapor-phase-etching process, and complex sample post-processing steps are eliminated. The spatial confinement effect of the template method enables control of the size, morphology, and structure of nanomaterials. 3 Conclusions In summary, the VEHT method combining the vapor etching process with the hard template method provides a platform to directly fabricate tubular structures, including for metal oxides and sulfides. The key feature of the VEHT method is that the vapor etching process of Sb2S3 hard templates can greatly simplify the steps involved in preparing tubular materials and avoid complicated post-processing procedures. The present new method can pave the way to preparing tubular materials with a wide range of applications. Moreover, in-situ heating TEM recorded the removal process of Sb2S3 template caused by the Rayleigh instability at high temperature, providing an intuitive understanding of the hard template disappearance process. So far as applications are concerned, taking TiO2− x tubes as an example, their unique tubular structure and massive oxygen defects make the TiO2− x tubes promising for numerous functional applications, especially due to their sodium-ion storage properties. They delivered an excellent capacity retention of 92.7% at the high current density of 5 A g−1 after 7000 cycles. Furthermore, tubular TiO2− x demonstrated excellent stability (capacity retention of 98% after 1000 cycles) in the Na-ion full cells. A paragraph briefly summaries the achievement of this work. coredata.dc:description: Inorganic tubular materials have an exceptionally wide range of applications, yet developing a simple and universal method to controllably synthesize them remains challenging. In this work, we report a vapor-phase-etching hard-template method that can directly fabricate tubes on various thermally stable oxide and sulfide materials. This synthesis method features the introduction of a vapor-phase-etching process to greatly simplify the steps involved in preparing tubular materials and avoids complicated post-processing procedures. Furthermore, the in-situ heating transmission electron microscopy (TEM) technique is used to observe the dynamic formation process of TiO2− x tubes, indicating that the removal process of the Sb2S3 templates first experienced the Rayleigh instability, then vapor-phase-etching process. When used as an anode for sodium ion batteries, the TiO2− x tube exhibits excellent rate performance of 134.6 mA h g−1 at the high current density of 10 A g− 1 and long-term cycling over 7000 cycles. Moreover, the full cell demonstrates excellent cycling performance with capacity retention of 98% after 1000 cycles, indicating that it is a promising anode material for batteries. This method can be expanded to the design and synthesis of other thermally-stable tubular materials such as ZnS, MoS2, and SiO2.

coredata.dc:title: A general synthesis of inorganic nanotubes as high-rate anode materials of sodium ion batteries
